results.title:
Abra Cadabra
(1983)
Clips from film
results.brief_description: Australian cartoonist Alexander Stitt is best known for creating the ‘Life. Be in It’ advertisements, along with characters from the ‘Slip-Slop-Slap’ ads, but in 1983 he made the first 3D animated film, Abra Cadabra.
results.description: Three-dimensional stereoscopic images were invented in 1838, but it took 145 years for the first 3D animated feature to be made. Australian cartoonist Alexander Stitt is best known for creating the ‘Life. Be in It’ advertisements, along with characters from the ‘Slip-Slop-Slap’ ads, but in 1983 he made Abra Cadabra. This 3D cosmic fantasy stars John Farnham and Jacki Weaver in an adaptation of the Pied Piper story. It creates depth by using the Triangle 3D anaglyph system and special ‘AbraGoggles’ designed by Stitt. Unfortunately, the sale of Channel Nine meant the film wasn’t released, but it did screen on Nickelodeon in the 1980s and at film festivals.
description_for_label: Three-dimensional stereoscopic images were invented in 1838, but it took 145 years for the first 3D animated feature to be made. Australian cartoonist Alexander Stitt is best known for creating the ‘Life. Be in It’ advertisements, along with characters from the ‘Slip-Slop-Slap’ ads, but in 1983 he made Abra Cadabra. This 3D cosmic fantasy stars John Farnham and Jacki Weaver in an adaptation of the Pied Piper story. It creates depth by using the Triangle 3D anaglyph system and special ‘AbraGoggles’ designed by Stitt. Unfortunately, the sale of Channel Nine meant the film wasn’t released, but it did screen on Nickelodeon in the 1980s and at film festivals.

results.title: Early handling of spinal injuries
results.creator_credit: Walford Hewitson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Accidents don’t happen”.
Shows what to do and what not to do in the way of on-the-spot first aid when industrial back injuries occur. Animation illustrates the structure of the spinal column and how paralysis may result from injury to the inner spinal cord. Detailed demonstrations, both in a factory and in a logging camp, show how an accident victim must be handled in order to avoid more serious complications.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Walford Hewitson and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Handling
results.creator_credit: Donald Mulholland, Fred Lasse and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Accidents don’t happen”.
A brief quiz on how, or how not, to handle heavy loads. In a two-minute test the audience is invited to spot nine mistakes in handling methods. Men are seen working with packing cases, cement sacks, oil drums and metal rods - and having trouble. After the test, the same workers are shown doing their jobs the right way.

results.title: The Bunyip and the Green Ban
results.creator_credit: SKA TV, Campbell Manderson and Pip Starr
results.brief_description: A local report on a residents’ fight to heritage list the Gentle Bunyip, an historic house in Clifton Hill. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Machines
results.creator_credit: Donald Mulholland, Fred Lasse and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Accidents don’t happen”.
Minor carelessness in handling machinery may lead to a major accident. Investigating a fatal accident involving a power saw, the film reconstructs the steps leading up to the fatality and shows the worker’s two key mistakes in handling the saw.

results.title: Fortress Goolengook
results.creator_credit: SKA TV, Campbell Manderson and Pip Starr
results.brief_description: After having their camp destroyed by loggers, forest blockaders in the heart of East Gippsland’s Goolengook forest build an elaborate fortress (including drawbridge!) to ensure their safety against further attacks. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Organization
results.creator_credit: Donald Mulholland, Fred Lasse and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Accidents don’t happen”.
How safety committees can lower the accident rate in industry. A typical committee is shown in action, investigating danger spots and reporting on hazards such as bad lighting and uneven floors. Careful training and supervision of new workers is also seen as a responsibility of the safety committee.
